entry.title: Thailand lockdown: Jobless and trapped migrant workers in limbo

media:group.media:title: Thailand lockdown: Jobless and trapped migrant workers in limbo
media:group.media:description:
Thailand's four million migrant workers are more vulnerable than ever after recent layoffs due to the COVID-19 pandemic. With most borders closed, thousands are stranded and relying on handouts. And there are fears their situation could get even worse once the country fully returns to work.
Al Jazeera’s Scott Heidler reports from Samut Sakhon in Thailand.

entry.title: Trump to withdraw US from Open Skies arms control treaty

media:group.media:title: Trump to withdraw US from Open Skies arms control treaty
media:group.media:description:
The United States has announced that it would pull out of the Open Skies treaty which allows member countries to conduct unarmed surveillance flights over 35 participating states. President Donald Trump said he was withdrawing the US from the treaty as Russia had repeatedly violated its terms. He said he intended to renegotiate - or get a new deal with Russia - and was interested in getting China on board.
Al Jazeera’s Rob Reynolds reports.

#Trump #Russia #OpenSkyTreaty

entry.title: Scotland lockdown: First minister announces lifting restrictions

media:group.media:title: Scotland lockdown: First minister announces lifting restrictions
media:group.media:description:
More than two weeks after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced an easing of coronavirus lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon has unveiled her plan for Scotland. The first minister is implementing different measures, at a slower pace, raising questions about how united the United Kingdom really is.
Al Jazeera's Halla Mohieddeen reports from Edinburgh, Scotland.

#UKcoronavirus #Scotland #NicolaSturgeon

entry.title: Hydroxychloroquine global trials: Drug to be tested on UK health workers

media:group.media:title: Hydroxychloroquine global trials: Drug to be tested on UK health workers
media:group.media:description:
An anti-malaria drug made famous by US President Donald Trump will now be trialled on front-line health workers in Europe, Africa, Asia and South America. This comes as many European nations are trying to navigate a way out of coronavirus lockdown restrictions.
Al Jazeera's Assed Baig reports.

#Coronavirus #Hydroxychloroquine #COVID19

entry.title: We meet COVID-19 survivors to hear their stories

media:group.media:title: We meet COVID-19 survivors to hear their stories
media:group.media:description:
Worldwide there have been more than five million cases of COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, and more than 328,000 deaths. While those numbers are shocking, the reality is the majority of those who contract the illness survive it.
Many people believe that having the virus is an experience akin with having the flu or a bad cold. Survivors, though, are telling different stories, in which many of them have experienced a rollercoaster of severe symptoms. Doctors are also investigating whether the virus could cause long-term health complications.
So what is it really like to have Covid-19 and come out the other side? In this episode of The Stream, we’re joined by a group of survivors to find out.
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#Aljazeeraenglish #News #AJStream

entry.title: Schools in lockdown: 13-year-old takes on role of teacher in Gaza

media:group.media:title: Schools in lockdown: 13-year-old takes on role of teacher in Gaza
media:group.media:description:
Millions of children around the world have missed school for months because of the coronavirus pandemic. In Gaza, a teenage girl has overcome the restrictions by becoming a teacher herself. Al Jazeera's Sara Khairat reports.

entry.title: US small businesses: Innovating to survive virus slow down

media:group.media:title: US small businesses: Innovating to survive virus slow down
media:group.media:description:
Some small businesses in the United States are finding a way to survive the economic conditions described as the worst since the Great Depression. Al Jazeera's Gabriel Elizondo reports from Montclair, New Jersey.

entry.title: Cyclone Amphan: India and Bangladesh clean up after devastation

media:group.media:title: Cyclone Amphan: India and Bangladesh clean up after devastation
media:group.media:description:
Clean up operations have begun in India and Bangladesh after the most powerful cyclone to hit the Bay of Bengal in 20 years. Cyclone Amphan killed at least 84 people and destroyed thousands of homes. There are now concerns about the spread of coronavirus in emergency shelters where millions of people sought safety. Al Jazeera's Elizabeth Puranam reports from New Delhi, India.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Bangladesh #India

entry.title: How will universities adapt to the coronavirus pandemic? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: How will universities adapt to the coronavirus pandemic? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
The coronavirus pandemic is disrupting higher education world wide. Lockdowns have closed university and college campuses. Classes have moved online. The University of Cambridge in the UK is the latest to make all lectures online until next year. But can virtual classes provide the same learning experience? And should students continue to pay high tuition fees so they can sit their exams?
Presenter: Bernard Smith
Guests: Jeffrey Seglin - Senior lecturer in public policy at Harvard Kennedy School
Aanya Wig - student at Lady Shri Ram College at the University of Delhi
Ryan Carson - Founder of the online tech school Treehouse
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #InsideStory #pandemic

entry.title: China congress: Leaders face unprecedented pressure

media:group.media:title: China congress: Leaders face unprecedented pressure
media:group.media:description:
Chinese leaders observed a minute of silence for coronavirus victims at the start of its biggest political gathering of the year. The opening session of China's top political advisory body started one day before the National People's Congress. The government is facing unprecedented pressure over its handling of the pandemic, tensions with the United States and a slowing economy hit hard by COVID-19. Al Jazeera's Katrina Yu reports from Beijing on that and other pressures faced by China's leaders.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #China #COVID19

entry.title: UK's divided response: Varied messages across four nations

media:group.media:title: UK's divided response: Varied messages across four nations
media:group.media:description:
The United Kingdom remains deeply divided over how to respond to the coronavirus pandemic. While restrictions have been eased in England, Scotland remains in lockdown. Al Jazeera's Halla Mohieddeen reports from Edinburgh, Scotland.

entry.title: France tourism looks to reopen as coronavirus restrictions ease

media:group.media:title: France tourism looks to reopen as coronavirus restrictions ease
media:group.media:description:
Spain and Greece are looking to reopen for tourism this summer but across Europe, the entire sector is preparing for a tough season. While some restrictions are being eased, it is expected to take until 2021 for the number of foreign visitors to rebound. The French government has yet to decide when borders, hotels, restaurants and cafes will fully reopen. Last week the Prime Minister announced a tourism rescue plan worth more than $19bn.
Al Jazeera's Natacha Butler reports from Paris.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#France #Coronavirus #FranceTourism

entry.title: Iran oil shipment: Venezuelan military to escort fuel tankers

media:group.media:title: Iran oil shipment: Venezuelan military to escort fuel tankers
media:group.media:description:
A new standoff could be brewing between the United States, Iran and Venezuela, over a shipment of millions of dollars of fuel. Five Iranian oil tankers are just days away from arriving in Venezuela to help ease fuel shortages there.
Venezuela's own oil refining industry collapsed; critics say that was because of underinvestment and mismanagement.
Al Jazeera’s Alexi O'Brien reports.

#Venezuela #Iran #VenezuelaFuelShortages

entry.title: Malaysia’s Ramadan bazaars go online amid pandemic

media:group.media:title: Malaysia’s Ramadan bazaars go online amid pandemic
media:group.media:description:
Ramadan is the holiest month in the Muslim calendar. In Malaysia it is also a time when small traders and hawkers make the most money. But as their shops remain closed because of the pandemic, many vendors have gone online.
Al Jazeera’s Florence Looi reports from Kuala Lumpur.

#Malaysia #Ramadan2020 #RamadanBazaar

entry.title: Burundi votes in tense presidential election

media:group.media:title: Burundi votes in tense presidential election
media:group.media:description:
People in Burundi have cast ballots to pick a successor to President Pierre Nkurunziza amid reports of political violence. Nkurunziza has been in power for 15 years and has been accused of human rights abuses. The polls were marred by concerns about a lack of transparency after international observers were barred.
Al Jazeera’s Malcolm Webb reports.
